{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3364670,"name":"Jaci","username":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T00:43:44.796Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

It’s my pleasure to announce the newest products from Grapple Robotics that we’re announcing at champs this year. But first, I’d like to announce that from today, Grapple Robotics will be partnering with The Thrifty Bot!

IMG_00852796×1290 365 KB

What does this partnership mean?

Really, it comes down to four things:

  • Grapple will stock The Thrifty Bot parts in our Australian store (starting with the most popular / critical components, and then expanding to a larger catalogue)
  • The Thrifty Bot will stock Grapple parts in their US store (which means cheaper shipping for the majority of teams!)
  • Grapple and Thrifty will co-develop a select range of future products
  • Grapple and Thrifty electronics products will be cross-compatible (i.e. Grapple and Thrifty CAN products will show up in GrappleHook, and follow a shared CAN specification)

We’ll be stocking each other’s components in our stores in the coming months, so stay tuned!

(Also, Grapple is still looking to stock other vendor’s parts in Australia – if you’re a vendor and haven’t seen an email from me yet, drop me a line!)

Come see us at worlds!

Unfortunately, I personally will not be at champs this year – however, The Thrifty Bot folks will be, and they’ll have our new products on show, including those mentioned below! Go check out their booth and see if you can spot these in the wild and get hands-on.

LaserCAN – Now with case!

We’re re-releasing the LaserCAN, now with an ESD-safe case developed by our friends at Thrifty, ready for deployment on your robots! For those in the US, these will be in stock in Thrifty’s store soon, where you can benefit from in-country shipping rates!

MitoCANdria – The Powerhouse of the Robot

New for the 2024 offseason is the MitoCANdria – a smart dual-rail power regulator ready for your robots. The MitoCANdria is perfect for powering single-board computers (like the Raspberry Pi, Orange Pi, or NVIDIA Jetson), LED strips, and more! The MitoCANdria features:

  • Lever-action WAGOs for input and output rails, locking Molex SL connectors for CAN
  • Vertical-entry USB and Output connectors to decrease horizontal footprint
  • 4.5V – 14V input voltage range (7.5V – 14V continuous, 4.5V – 20V transient)
  • 120W continuous, 150W transient power output
  • Approx. 125mm x 50mm (~5x2in)
  • 90%+ Efficiency at full load
  • Current monitoring on every channel
  • 2x 5V switchable channels, 2x 5V non-switchable USB Type C channels (5A per channel, up to 10A shared)
  • 1x 15V – 24V adjustable, switchable channel (5A limit) – configurable over CAN
  • Dual-rail output filtering built for FRC

Note: we’re still validating the power rating and efficiency numbers of the MitoCANdria – these numbers are preliminary based off a prototype revision. The below image is also slightly newer than the model on display at champs and is physically smaller.

IMG_00862334×1097 250 KB

Our partners at Thrifty are designing a case for the MitoCANdria, and we will be looking at getting these in the hands of some select teams for beta testing within the next month. Once we’re sure they can withstand the punishment of FRC, we’ll be releasing them for purchase!

FlexiCAN – One Core, Many Possibilities

Also new for the 2024 offseason is the FlexiCAN – a 37.5x37.5mm (~1.5x1.5in) board designed to be a flexible core module for any number of carrier devices. On the bottom of the FlexiCAN are a pair of mezzanine connectors that connect it to a carrier device of your choice – an LED matrix, an Arduino-style breakout, or a custom board designed by your team or other vendors.

  • 37.5x37.5mm package
  • CAN FD and CAN 2.0 compatible (future-proof)
  • User-programmable in several languages
  • 5.5V – 18V input voltage
  • Regulated 5V @ 1A rail provided to the carrier board
  • USB-CAN Bridge Support with GrappleHook (open standard)

The FlexiCAN runs a lightweight WASM interpreter, allowing users to upload their own code while letting the FlexiCAN handle low-level peripherals. You can target WASM from JavaScript, C++, Rust, and more! For official Grapple carrier boards (like the LED Matrix), you can also go purely with the software built into the FlexiCAN’s firmware without having to write your own software.

IMG_00871232×1181 205 KB

Currently, we have two carrier boards – an LED Matrix, and a general Breakout. The LED matrix uses a set of 14x WS2812B LEDs, exposing the full gamut of brightness and colour to the user. The in-built LEDs require no additional power regulation circuitry to function, and additional compatible WS2812B-based LED strips can be attached to the on-board JST connector, which can be snipped off if unused (note: this JST connector does not provide power).

IMG_00881226×1138 175 KB

We have more carrier boards planned (Arduino-compatible breakout, physical autonomous selector to name a few), but we’d love to hear your ideas! If you have an idea for a carrier board, let us know – who knows, maybe we’ll make it!

… and one more thing

Don’t worry – we’ll have even more products ready for the 2025 season. This is but a sneak peek

Best,

Jaci

I’ve been wanting a CAN connected regulator for a while, that looks great!. For the MitoCANdria you mention transient input range of 4.5-14V, but especially with the latest brushless motors, voltage transients can be over 16V or higher. And in the case of no battery teams have been reporting frying Limelights with these transients. Is 14V the final number, or would you consider a higher input voltage range?

Max_Morehead:

Is it weird that that in a post full of amazing announcements, this is the most exciting? Seems like a big step towards a open and cross-compatible FRC CAN standard.

We are working on a proposal regarding an open CAN standard designed specifically for FRC - hoping to share more soon

Max_Morehead:

Will the firmware for FlexiCAN and MitoCANdria be open source?

Since the MitoCANdria and FlexiCAN are joint products between Grapple and Thrifty, this is still something we’re figuring out. At the very least, we will definitely be sharing our CAN infrastructure in the open source domain (including messaging formats, fragmentation/defragmentation, etc). For the FlexiCAN, there will be a WASM stack that will be open-sourced to allow teams to build whatever code they like on top of the FlexiCAN’s base.

Jaci:

1x 15V – 24V adjustable, switchable channel (5A limit) – configurable over CAN

Is that a typo from 5V to 15V by any chance? If not, what use case did you have in mind for it?

We’ll be opening up orders for the LaserCAN again once we get the kitting fully sorted out (case and all), so hopefully within the next month or two I may make another revision of the LaserCAN at some point which supports FD, but it’s not currently on the cards.

In theory, the CAN FD devices should be compatible with a CANivore when running at 8Mbps, but CTRE doesn’t expose their interface for other vendors. The FlexiCAN will also behave like a CAN FD ↔ USB bridge like the CANivore, but will be open to all vendors, but it will ultimately be up to their API whether they support it or not.

I’m afraid not; the ADJ rail is pure boost, which means the minimum voltage must be at least the robot battery voltage. Most FRC electronics including sensors, the Radio, and notably the Limelight support at least 15V so you can provide a regulated power rail to those. 19V is also a target for mini PCs and more power-hungry SBCs. 24V is also the maximum for FRC (at least in the current rules), and is a common industrial voltage.

We’re currently targetting some time in June - we’ve slotted in time for another 1-2 prototyping runs and beta testing. After that, assuming they pass their tests with flying colours, they’ll be available for purchase. Our current lead time for prototypes to be manufactured is about 2 weeks, and we’d like to allow time for teams to put them through their paces.

Primitive CAN read/writes will be available to the user, including both arbitrary-ID frames and those dedicated for Team Use (Manufacturer ID = 8). The reads will be polling due to a limitation in WASM, but they will be buffered and exposed like they are in the embedded-hal ecosystem (i.e. you choose a Message ID and Message Mask to listen for, and apply that as a filter on the bus).

This is indeed how it functions - all switchable output channels are locked off until one of two things happen:

  • The voltage is set from the RoboRIO and the channel explicitly turned on
  • A configuration is loaded at startup with the above already loaded

All switchable outputs are electrically off by default, so if the microcontroller breaks the channels will remain off.

Configurations are persistently stored, so whatever state the MitoCANdria was in last will be what it loads at startup.

The adjustable channel has additional protections - the channel won’t be enabled until the rail is in an acceptable voltage range, and has overvoltage lockout protection to avoid temporary overvoltage conditions from frying downstream boards.
